results.headline: A Happy Ersatz Family, in a Yurt

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hyazgar

results.summary_short: Silence, interrupted only by the periodic violent howls of the wind and animal mewls and bleats, pervades the otherworldly landscape of “Desert Dream.”

results.headline: Possess Glittery Magic Orb, Do Martial Arts, Save World

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dragonball Evolution

results.summary_short: “Dragonball” has been perfectly designed to blow the mind of a 10-year-old boy.

results.headline: A Stockbroker in Training Has Turns in His Journey

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Mysteries of Pittsburgh

results.summary_short: “The Mysteries of Pittsburgh” is a clumsy and confused adaptation of Michael Chabon’s 1988 novel.

results.headline: A Father’s Legacy

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of In a Dream

results.summary_short: “In a Dream” belongs to the dubious subgenre of the aggrandized home movie — but in this case, what a home!

results.headline: Headbanging at Windmills Once More

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Anvil! The Story of Anvil

results.summary_short: The earnest, heartfelt striving of the two men at the center of Anvil makes the band’s story more touching than comical.

results.headline: A Dark Glimpse From Eddie Adams’s Camera

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of An Unlikely Weapon

results.summary_short: Like many documentaries about talented people who did important things during amazing times, “An Unlikely Weapon: The Eddie Adams Story” tends to fall into repetitive fawning.

results.headline: Mall Crisis? Call Security. Then Again, Maybe Not.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Observe and Report

results.summary_short: If you thought Abu Ghraib was a laugh riot then you might love “Observe and Report.”

results.headline: OMG! Hannah on the Big Screen

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hannah Montana: The Movie

results.summary_short: Does “Hannah Montana: The Movie” translate well from television?

results.headline: Humble Hope in Hard Times

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Pope's Toilet

results.summary_short: “The Pope’s Toilet” cloaks religious critique in the scrappy tempo of irremediable poverty and irrepressible enterprise.

results.headline: Ticks, Ennui and (Sigh) the Dream Girl Next Door

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Lymelife

results.summary_short: Despite some floundering, “Lymelife” keeps you hooked, mostly through its performances.

results.headline: Fictional Realities

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Forbidden Lie$

results.summary_short: Cool-headed, lighthearted and outrageously entertaining, “Forbidden Lie$” is documentary-as-striptease.

results.headline: Diamond in the Rough

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sugar

results.summary_short: “Sugar” is infused with a deep affection for baseball, the rhythms of which are captured by a narrative pace and editing style that quicken and relax as necessary.

results.headline: Losing His Soul, Then Finding It Again, After a Season in Hell

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Song of Sparrows

results.summary_short: “The Song of Sparrows” is really a series of strict moral lessons pieced together into an austere Islamic sermon.

results.headline: Surviving Inside a Decaying Museum

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Escapist

results.summary_short: “The Escapist” shapes a standard prison-break drama into a metaphysical study of freedom and reparation.

results.headline: Coming of Age on the Midway

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Adventureland

results.summary_short: The story of a young man’s coming of age never gets old, at least when it is told with the kind of sweetness and intelligence “Adventureland” displays.

results.headline: Monsters, Aliens and Nostalgia

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Alien Trespass

results.summary_short: “Alien Trespass” is a charmingly sentimental but ultimately pointless homage to the sci-fi classics of yesteryear.

results.headline: Cue the Accordions: Baguettes, Berets and Léon Blum

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Paris 36

results.summary_short: There is plenty of evidence to support the argument that French film is alive and well. And then there is “Paris 36.”

results.headline: Fraught Family Dynamics

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Lifelines

results.summary_short: Written and directed by Rob Margolies, “Lifelines” starts promisingly, but soon gives way to a compressed, schematic psychodrama endemic.

results.headline: The Swagger of Fathers, the Drift of Children

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Gigantic

results.summary_short: The mood of “Gigantic,” a cautiously surreal, absurdist movie, is predominantly glum.

results.headline: Burning Rubber One More Time

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fast & Furious

results.summary_short: This example of presummer pop diversion will be best appreciated by future audiences flabbergasted by its unabashed revelry in fossil-fuel consumption.
